items.title: Should 'limit' not, um, limit the number of items or pages returned?
items.body:
_Warning_: Github issues are not an official support channel for Recurly. If you have an urgent request we suggest you contact us through an official channel: support@recurly.com or https://recurly.zendesk.com
Per the documentation: 

> All client.*_list methods return a Pager. On the pager, pages() returns a PageIterator and items() returns an ItemIterator.

I have understand that I can pass a limit to the list method like so:

> accounts = client.list_accounts(limit=200).items()
for account in accounts:
    print(account.code)

However, doing so does not limit the number of items returned in any way that I would consider conventional. For example, the above code snippet will return exponentially more than 200 results from the Recurly account I'm working on.

I reached out to Recurly support, and they provided this somewhat confusing reply:

> "The limit parameter impacts the number of results that are returned per API request. The Pager will continue to make API requests, in a manner that is you, until the entire record set is exhausted."

> "For example, let's say we have a total of 100 Subscriptions in total. If you specify a limit of 100 then there will be a single API request that returns all 100 records. However, if you specify a limit of 50, then there will be 2 API requests required to consume all of the records."

I can't think of a use case for wanting to have two API requests for 50 records vs. one request for 100, nor another API where a ```limit``` works this way.

Can you clarify how you expect limit to work in this client library?

Phillip.

items.title: Missing API call for listing account subscriptions
items.body:
Current python v3 API library is missing a function for listing account subscriptions.

I managed to add it on my local environment in the `client.py` file:

```python
    def list_account_subscriptions(self, account_id):
        """List an account's subscriptions

        Parameters
        ----------
        account_id : str
            Account ID or code. For ID no prefix is used e.g. `e28zov4fw0v2`. For code use prefix `code-`, e.g. `code-bob`.

        Keyword Arguments
        =================
        
        Returns
        -------
        Pager
            A list of the account's subscriptions.
        """
        path = self._interpolate_path("/accounts/%s/subscriptions", account_id)
        return Pager(self, path, kwargs)
```

Used this in a quick project and seemed to work.

items.title: Missing timezone in parsed dates
items.body:

Datetime attributes are missing the timezone information after being parsed. 
Recurly API returns datetimes as iso8601, but tz is lost while parsing these fields and building the resources.

**To Reproduce**

Just fetch any entity with a datetime field and query the `tzinfo` property. For example:

```
subscription = client.get_subscription("...")
subscription.current_period_started_at.tzinfo # None
```

Datetime should have timezone information.

I believe the problem is using `strptime` here: https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/master/recurly/resource.py#L91

What about using `dateutil.parser.parse`?

**Your Environment**

- Which version of this library are you using? **3.3.0**
- Which version of the language are you using? **3.8.0**

items.title: Unable to distinguish server and client errors in versions >= 3.0.0
items.body:
Errors that are a result of a temporary problem with the server (500-599 response code) and errors that are a result of something the user needs to do differently (400-499 response code) should be possible to differentiate. From version 3.0.0 many of these errors inherit from recurly.ApiError and when an error code not explicitly captured is returned by the API an ApiError is raised. As a user of this client I _need_ to be able to differentiate between errors that are a result of a temporary API outage and errors that are a result of my code.

This was a solved problem in 2.x versions with ServerError/ClientError and UnexpectedServerError/UnexpectedClientError:
https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/2.9.11/recurly/errors.py#L276

I can submit a PR if this sounds acceptable. This is the solution I'm suggesting:
* Add a ServerError/ClientError that inherit from recurly.APIError and add it as parent to every Error class here: https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/2e64eb23fce75d946a0af65f5c6c5d3c66757953/recurly/errors.py#L9
* Raise ServerError or ClientError here depending on the value of resp.status and include the value of resp.status in the error message: https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/2e64eb23fce75d946a0af65f5c6c5d3c66757953/recurly/base_client.py#L58
* ApiError should still be raised if a response code > 599 is returned. The value of resp.status should be included in the error message

items.title: Access the three_d_secure_action_token_id from the ValidationError
items.body:
**Describe the bug**
We are implementing the PSD2 flow needed for **September 14th**. I've had a ticket open with the recurly support for the last week without resolution and the deadline is fast approaching, hence why I'm opening this github issue. 

Using the Python Recurly client and creating a subscription, we get a ValidationError stating a 3ds secure challenge is needed. Exactly as described here: https://dev.recurly.com/page/recurly-3d-secure-2-integration-guide#section--step-3-process-the-purchase-response.

In the ValidationError, there is no way (that I'm aware of) to retrieve the three_d_secure_action_token_id. I need to get this token to send back so our frontend can initiate the flow. 

In short: 
- Our frontend sends us a token and a plan. 
- From our backend using this python SDK: 
-- Create an account if necessary
-- Create a subscription <- this is where we would handle the 3ds secure and retrieve the token.

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior.

Generate a token (that requires the 3ds secure flow), from your doc above, using the credit card here: `4000000000003220 - challenge flow`

then, with the token_id created from there, do:
```python
import recurly
# recurly config
account = recurly.Account(account_code=1234)
account.save()
billing_info = recurly.BillingInfo(token_id=token_id)
subscription = recurly.Subscription(
    plan_code="plan_code",
    account=account)
try:
    subscription.save()
except recurly.ValidationError as e:
    # Here I want to be able to handle the error if it's a 3ds validation error, get the token and send it to my front. How do I access the three_d_secure_action_token_id from e? 
```


**Expected behavior**

A simple method call or attribute on the error to retrieve the token. 
```
3ds_token = e.three_d_secure_action_token_id
```

**Your Environment**

- Which version of this library are you using?
-> 2.9.9
- Which version of python are you using?
-> Python 3.6.8

items.title: Add exception class to differentiate server errors that raise UnexpectedStatusError from other status codes
items.body:
At the moment in my application I assume ServerError captures all possible server errors. This is not the case as I've occasionally seen 530s and at any time a new 5xx code could be used. Handling UnexpectedStatusError as well and branching behavior based on status codes is tricky given my application's current structure. It would be much simpler to have a set of exception classes that I can assume are server errors.

I'm proposing:
* A new class UnexpectedServerError that inherits from UnexpectedStatusError (possibly also ServerError) and is used for any unexpected (not in error_classes) status codes in the range 500-599
* A new class UnexpectedClientError that inherits from UnexpectedStatusError (possibly also ClientError) and is used for any unexpected (not in error_classes) status codes in the range 400-499
* Any other status codes still use UnexpectedStatusError as they do now.
* Possibly a dedicated class that inherits from ServerError to handle 530s if someone knows how these are used by the recurly API. I don't have full logs of those errors so I don't know what the full status line is.

items.title: Avoid using StopIteration inside of generator
items.body:
Current behavior of StopIteration inside of a generator is accidental and has been deprecated, at least as of python 3.6:
https://docs.python.org/3.6/whatsnew/3.5.html#whatsnew-pep-479

Using StopIteration this way (at least in python 3.6) results in the following warning, and will result in a RuntimeError in future versions of python:
```
DeprecationWarning: generator 'Page.__iter__' raised StopIteration
```

Instead of raising a StopIteration, the Page class should use the return or yield keyword as appropriate:
https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/967a92a2f866174d204468f04b2865b311caa9fe/recurly/resource.py#L90

items.title: Wrong constructor for Resource autogenerates "currency" attribute
items.body:
The __init__() of BillingInfo (and any Resource) creates a self.currency attribute, as seen here :

```
import recurly
BI = recurly.BillingInfo(**{'token_id': 'TOTO'})
BI.currency    # gives eg. "USD"
```
However, when creating a BillingInfo record this way, and using it to purchase a subscription, this leads to an error :

> billing_info_invalid: no other attributes are allowed when a token is provided

Resource constructor shouldn't autogenerate attributes which will then break the assumptions of misc. account/subscription APIs

```
good_str_func = recurly.errors.ValidationError.__str__
recurly.errors.ValidationError.Suberror.__str__ = good_str_func
```

items.title: Improper refreshing of Resource objects after an action
items.body:
When calling save() on a new Account (with attached BillingInfo), for example, the resource isn't properly updated, some of its attributes are stale. Among which "self.billing_info", which is still the old data sent to server, not the new one with updated tiemstamps and auto-generated tokens.

This is due to update_from_element() only deleting attributes from "cls.attributes",  a list which is often incomplete. Instead, the whole local data should be removed/replaced.

    The error was returned as a ``400 Bad Request`` response.
    Resubmitting the request will likely result in the same error.
    """
    pass
`

items.title: Subscription.save() bug
items.body:
If you have a subscription with a pending quantity change for instance:

quantity: 1
pending_quantity: 3

If you get that subscription and then save it:
subscription.save()

It will override the pending quantity so we will just have:

quantity: 1
And no pending changes.

items.title: ValidationError override multiple errors on the same field
items.body:
Hi!

When you have a validation error with multiple errors on the same field, only the last message is kept.

Eg. On a subscription error you can have a xml like that:
```xml

<errors>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.address1" symbol="empty">can't be empty</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.city" symbol="empty">can't be empty</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.country" symbol="empty">can't be empty</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.first_name" symbol="blank">can't be blank</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.last_name" symbol="blank">can't be blank</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.number" symbol="required">is required</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.billing_info.zip" symbol="empty">can't be empty</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.account_code" symbol="blank">can't be blank</error>
  <error field="subscription.account.account_code" symbol="invalid">is invalid</error>
  <error field="subscription.plan_code" symbol="invalid">is invalid</error>
  <error field="subscription.unit_amount_in_cents" symbol="not_a_number">is not a number</error>
</errors>
```
And the python representation of the error is:
```python

In [98]: try:
    ...:     recurly.Subscription(account=recurly.Account(billing_info=recurly.BillingInfo())).save()
    ...: except recurly.ValidationError as err:
    ...:     pass
    ...:     

In [99]: print(err)
not_a_number: subscription.unit_amount_in_cents is not a number; invalid: subscription.plan_code is invalid; required: subscription.account.billing_info.number is required; empty: subscription.account.billing_info.address1 can't be empty; blank: subscription.account.billing_info.last_name can't be blank; blank: subscription.account.billing_info.first_name can't be blank; empty: subscription.account.billing_info.country can't be empty; empty: subscription.account.billing_info.zip can't be empty; empty: subscription.account.billing_info.city can't be empty; invalid: subscription.account.account_code is invalid

In [100]: err.errors
Out[100]: 
{'subscription.account.account_code': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b0ece8c90>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.address1': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b1c161cd0>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.city': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b1c161590>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.country': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b1c161850>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.first_name': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b1c161390>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.last_name': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b1c161190>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.number': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b0ece8290>,
 'subscription.account.billing_info.zip': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b0ece8dd0>,
 'subscription.plan_code': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b0ece8810>,
 'subscription.unit_amount_in_cents': <recurly.errors.Suberror at 0x7f0b0ece8fd0>}

```
We see that we only have one ```subscription.account.account_code``` instead of two

Could we have a list of suberrors as a value of the dict instead of just one suberror ?

The code is located here: https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/master/recurly/errors.py#L238
```python
suberrors = dict()
for err in self.response_doc.findall('error'):
    field = err.attrib['field']
    symbol = err.attrib['symbol']
    message = err.text

    suberrors[field] = self.Suberror(field, symbol, message)

self.__dict__['errors'] = suberrors
```
Maybe use a defaultdict(list) instead of a dict ?

I also see a variable for a `PRIVATE_KEY` (`recurly.js.PRIVATE_KEY`). However, I can not find where to get that key within Recurly. Where do I find this key?

Also, looking through the code, it appears that `PRIVATE_KEY` is only used in `recurly.js.sign` and `recurly.js.sign` is not used anywhere. Is this key necessary anymore?

items.title: Errors unprintable in python 3.5.0 / client 2.2.17
items.body:
When I get a traceback from the recurly client, what I see is this:

```
recurly.errors.ValidationError: <unprintable ValidationError object>
```

Digging further, it seems to be caused by a nested exception, thrown in the `__unicode__`/`__str__` methods:

```
 File "<snip>/lib/python3.5/site-packages/recurly/errors.py", line 53, in __str__
    return self.__unicode__()
  File "<snip>/lib/python3.5/site-packages/recurly/errors.py", line 184, in __unicode__
    return six.u('; ').join(six.text_type(error) for error in self.errors.itervalues())
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'itervalues'
```

This is probably a python 3.X issue, as `itervalues()` was removed in favor of `values()`.

items.title: account.billing_info raises AttributeError on new accounts.
items.body:
Repeat of #98, but I'm having this occur in 2.2.17. I should note I'm on python 3.5.0, just in case.

Using the example in the docs for creating a new account, and then a new billing info object:

``` py
account = Account(account_code='1')
account.email = 'verena@example.com'
account.first_name = 'Verena'
account.last_name = 'Example'
account.save()

# account.billing_info here raises AttributeError, 
# so I copy-paste the example code exactly, including the get.

account = Account.get('1')
billing_info = account.billing_info #  but this still raises an AttributeError!
billing_info.token_id = 'TOKEN_ID'
billing_info.save()
```

I seem to have been able to resolve this by calling `account.update_billing_info` with a new BillingInfo object I create and add the token to, like so:

``` py
account = Account.get('1')
billing_info = BillingInfo()
billing_info.token_id = 'TOKEN_ID'
account.update_billing_info(billing_info)
```

Before I arrived to the solution above, I also tried attaching the billing info object I created to the account and saving it, but that raised an unrelated AttributeError, so I didn't continue down that path. 

While I have a solution that works for me as-is, I'm curious as to whether this is intended to be used this way, or if I'm going against the grain, since the example differed from my implementation. 

Thanks for your time!

items.title: Cannot manually expire a coupon redemption on an account
items.body:
[Documentation](https://dev.recurly.com/docs/remove-a-coupon-from-an-account) suggests that it is possible to expire single coupon redemption at a time. However, this raises a `NotFoundError`, with the following stack trace:

``` python
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 673, in delete
    self.raise_http_error(response)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 685, in raise_http_error
    raise exc_class(response_xml)
NotFoundError: No route matches [DELETE] "/v2/accounts/{{replaced account code}}/redemptions/{{replaced redemption uuid}}s/{{replaced redemption uuid}}"
```

Correct url for expiring the coupon redemption seems to be

```
https://:subdomain.recurly.com/v2/accounts/:account_code/redemptions/:uuid
```

This is according to above mentioned documentation and by trying it out by monkey patching the `delete_url` method on `Redemption` class.

Current implementation of `delete_url()` is as follows:

``` python
    def delete_url(self):
      return self._url + "s/" + self.uuid
```

But the `redemption._url` (returned by api) is already in the form

```
https://your-subdomain.recurly.com/v2/accounts/:account_id/redemptions/:redemption_uuid
```

and thus concatenating the `"s/"` and `uuid` once more breaks it.

items.title: Handling `unicode` in recurly configuration
items.body:
I was trying to create accounts from the API of Recurly using the Python client. Python 2.7, recurly 2.2.17

When creating a new account with a first name (or any other attribute actually) containing non-ascii characters (fetched as a `unicode`), saving the entity raises `UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte [...]`

A simple `account.first_name = u'Frédérique-Fançois'.encode('utf-8')` still raises the same error but at another level in the module.

For more details about the problem see this [stackoverflow post](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33783783/recurly-python-client-raising-unicodedecodeerror-when-supplying-non-ascii-charac).

This gist reproduces the problem and explains the details of the problem: [code](https://gist.github.com/maximehardy/d3a0a6427d2b6791b3dc)

To sum up the solution is to ensure that parameters like `recurly.API_KEY` come into `httplib` headers as `str`.

I think that documentation about the issue would be a good start, but going further you could either raise an error if configuration values are `unicode` or you could force a conversion (but be careful with encoding).

items.title: Invoice redemption() method throwing IndexError: list index out of range
items.body:
Reported by @whiteotter 

When calling redemption() on an invoice that is returning an empty <redemptions /> array:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 14, in <module>
    redemption = invoice.redemption()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/__init__.py", line 621, in redemption
    return self.redemptions()[0]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

My initial thoughts are that this should be returning None in the case that the array is empty.

May want to check that other overrides of `redemption()` are handling this correctly as well.

items.title: Errors attaching AddOns to plans and SubscriptionAddOn to Subscriptions
items.body:
According to docs, I can create an `AddOn` like this:

``` python
addon1 = recurly.AddOn(
    add_on_code='ipaddresses',
    name='Extra IP Addresses',
    unit_amount_in_cents=200
)
print addon1
<recurly.AddOn object at 0x7f05b52da510>
```

However, when you call `plan.create_add_on(addon1)`, it errors due to `unit_amount_in_cents`:

``` python
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/__init__.py", line 833, in create_add_on
    return add_on.post(url)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 658, in post
    self.raise_http_error(response)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 683, in raise_http_error
    raise exc_class(response_xml)
recurly.errors.ValidationError: blank: add_on.unit_amount_in_cents can't be blank
```

To get around this issue, as shown in tests, it works to use a `recurly.Money()` resource object (although it feels wrong):

``` python
addon1 = recurly.AddOn(
    add_on_code='ipaddresses',
    name='Extra IP Addresses',
    unit_amount_in_cents=recurly.Money(4)
)
plan.create_add_on(addon1)
[<recurly.AddOn object at 0x7f05b52c1f50>]
```

Using the Money resource object here instead of an integer creates an issue creating/attaching a `SubscriptionAddOn` to a subscription:

``` python
sub_addon = recurly.SubscriptionAddOn(add_on_code=addon1.add_on_code)
my_sub.subscription_add_ons = [sub_addon]
s.save()
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 632, in save
    return self._update()
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/__init__.py", line 637, in _update
    return super(Subscription, self)._update()
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 636, in _update
    return self.put(self._url)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 647, in put
    self.raise_http_error(response)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 683, in raise_http_error
    raise exc_class(response_xml)
recurly.errors.ValidationError: blank: subscription.subscription_add_ons[add_on_code=ipaddresses].unit_amount_in_cents can't be blank; invalid: subscription.subscription_add_ons[add_on_code=ipaddresses].add_on is invalid
```

To get around this error, you can override the `unit_amount_in_cents` with an integer when creating the `SubscriptionAddOn` as shown in docs:

``` python
my_sub.subscription_add_ons = []
tempaddon = recurly.SubscriptionAddOn()
tempaddon.add_on_code = 'ipaddresses'
tempaddon.quantity = 1
tempaddon.unit_amount_in_cents = 162
my_sub.subscription_add_ons.append(tempaddon)
my_sub.save()
```

This fixes the `unit_amount_in_cents` but not the `add_on` error: 

``` python
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 632, in save
    return self._update()
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/__init__.py", line 637, in _update
    return super(Subscription, self)._update()
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 636, in _update
    return self.put(self._url)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 647, in put
    self.raise_http_error(response)
  File "/home/vagrant/.virtualenvs/api/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/recurly/resource.py", line 683, in raise_http_error
    raise exc_class(response_xml)
recurly.errors.ValidationError: invalid: subscription.subscription_add_ons[add_on_code=ipaddresses].add_on is invalid
```

I can recreate the error [here](https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/master/tests/test_resources.py#L161-L166), by removing the try and add `unit_amount_in_cents=200` to the AddOn

items.body:

```
            def reopen(self):
```

items.title: Use of SSLv3 is insecure
items.body:
Hi,
As you may have seen in the news (this was already an accepted security best practice but now it's official ;) ), SSLv3 is now considered insecure and must be banned from all secured services ASAP.

Upstream also advises it: https://docs.python.org/2/library/ssl.html#ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv3

Can you please fix https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/master/recurly/resource.py#L195 to use PROTOCOL_TLSv1, or even better PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2?

Thanks!
Milton

items.title: Python XML vulnerabilities in objects_for_push_notification
items.body:
objects_for_push_notification uses xml.etree.ElementTree which is vulnerabilities to DOS attacks (see https://docs.python.org/2/library/xml.html#xml-vulnerabilities). This becomes an issue if for example the source IP of the request is not verified before parsing the request, or if the recurly service is compromised.

To reproduce:

``` python
>>> BILLION_LAUGHS = '''<!DOCTYPE lolz [
...  <!ENTITY lol "lol">
...  <!ELEMENT lolz (#PCDATA)>
...  <!ENTITY lol1 "&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;&lol;">
...  <!ENTITY lol2 "&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;&lol1;">
...  <!ENTITY lol3 "&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;&lol2;">
...  <!ENTITY lol4 "&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;&lol3;">
...  <!ENTITY lol5 "&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;&lol4;">
...  <!ENTITY lol6 "&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;&lol5;">
...  <!ENTITY lol7 "&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;&lol6;">
...  <!ENTITY lol8 "&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;&lol7;">
...  <!ENTITY lol9 "&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;&lol8;">
... ]>
... <lolz>&lol9;</lolz>'''
>>> recurly.objects_for_push_notification(BILLION_LAUGHS)
```

items.title: Cannot install using pip 1.4
items.body:
It is currently not possible to install version 2.1.10 of the Recurly client using the latest version of pip (1.4) released on 2013-07-23. 

Looking at the [release notes](http://www.pip-installer.org/en/latest/news.html#id1), it appears pip 1.4 no longer installs pre-release versions of packages by default. 

Recurly client depends on backports.ssl-match-hostname 3.2a3 which appears to be a pre-release version and therefore breaks installation. 

To reproduce, upgrade to pip 1.4 and then run `pip install recurly==2.1.10`. 

Output:

```
(env)test: pip install recurly==2.1.10
Downloading/unpacking recurly==2.1.10
  Downloading recurly-2.1.10.tar.gz
  Running setup.py egg_info for package recurly

Downloading/unpacking iso8601 (from recurly==2.1.10)

  Running setup.py egg_info for package iso8601

Downloading/unpacking backports.ssl-match-hostname (from recurly==2.1.10)

Cleaning up...
```

items.title: Handling Embedded objects
items.body:
The python library does not handle embedded objects well.  For instance the add_ons need to be fully replaced in order to update them.   Example:

newaddon = SubscriptionAddOn()
newaddon.add_on_code = 'my-new-add-on'
newaddon.quantity = 2
add_ons = subscription.subscription_add_ons
# need to copy old add-ons

subscription.subscription_add_ons = []
for a in add_ons:
    tempaddon = SubscriptionAddOn()
    tempaddon.add_on_code = a.add_on_code
    tempaddon.quantity = a.quantity
    tempaddon.unit_amount_in_cents = a.unit_amount_in_cents
    subscription.subscription_add_ons.append(tempaddon)
# append new add-on

subscription.subscription_add_ons.append(newaddon)
# 
# Adjust the quantity of one add-on
# 
# need to copy old add-ons

add_ons = subscription.subscription_add_ons
subscription.subscription_add_ons = []
for a in add_ons:
    tempaddon = SubscriptionAddOn()
    tempaddon.add_on_code = a.add_on_code
    tempaddon.quantity = a.quantity
    #check for a specific add-on
    if tempaddon.add_on_code == 'my-new-add-on':
        tempaddon.quantity = 6
    tempaddon.unit_amount_in_cents = a.unit_amount_in_cents
    subscription.subscription_add_ons.append(tempaddon)
# 
# Remove one add-on
# 

add_ons = subscription.subscription_add_ons
subscription.subscription_add_ons = []
for a in add_ons:
    if a.add_on_code != 'my-new-add-on':
        tempaddon = SubscriptionAddOn()
        tempaddon.add_on_code = a.add_on_code
        tempaddon.quantity = a.quantity
        tempaddon.unit_amount_in_cents = a.unit_amount_in_cents
        subscription.subscription_add_ons.append(tempaddon)

items.title: Refunding transactions fails
items.body:
Refunding transaction fails in the recurly Python library. The request is executed successfully, however the recurly API returns 202 (Accepted), not 200, 201, or 204, and thus is treated like an error response.

The problem is here:
https://github.com/recurly/recurly-client-python/blob/master/recurly/resource.py#L437

items.title: Transactions fail with validation error for users with a positive balance
items.body:
Here's a snippet that succeeds when the user has no account balance, but fails when they have an account balance and you submit a transaction for an amount smaller than their available balance:

```
account = recurly.Account(account_code='jordan+oTAHmuzG@prehype.com')
transaction = recurly.Transaction(amount_in_cents=1200, currency='USD', account=account)
transaction.save()
```

In this example, I'm charging the user $12.  If their account has a current balance of $11 (or anything else less than $12), this call will succeed.  If their account has a balance of $13 (or anything greater than $12), this call will fail with a ValidationError.

items.title: Subscription add-ons' unit amounts shouldn't be Money instances
items.body:
In an API response with a Subscription with a `subscription_add_ons` member, the add-ons' `unit_amount_in_cents` are modeled as `Money` instances. However, the matching `currency` for those Money instances is on the Subscription, not the add-on, so something goes awry and they can't be used.

The add-ons should be consistent with their Subscriptions, where the amounts are plain integers.

items.title: subscription.attributes lists nonexistant plan_code
items.body:
the .attributes property for subscription objects includes attributes that don't actually exist on the object.  I've seen this in other objects, too, so I don't think it's specific to that model.

For example, 'plan_code' is listed in the subscription model's "attributes" list, but a subscription object has no 'plan_code' attribute.

Therefore, the following fails:

```
account = recurly.Account.get('some_email@example.com')
subscriptions = account.subscriptions()
sub = subscriptions[0]
'plan_code' in sub.attributes # returns true
sub.plan_code # throws attribute error
```

However, the plan_code _is_ available for this object by the following mechanism:

`sub.plan.plan_code`

A break in the attributes list means that you can't really do anything dynamic with the attributes list, like create a dictionary with the object:

`dict((attrib, getattr(sub, attrib)) for attrib in sub.attributes)`

As a result, it's impossible to create a general mechanism for transforming a Recurly object.  With the dictionary example, it means that it's impossible to create a mechanism to render arbitrary Recurly objects in a web page; you would have to write a custom render function for every class exposed by the API if you wanted to do that.

The attributes list appears to be used erroneously by the client library itself.  For example, the .to_element method generates an xml.etree.ElementTree.Element object, but fails silently at generating elements for the attributes in the attribute list that do not really exist.  As a result, if you use .to_element on a subscription object, the Element instance that is returned is not representative of what the API returns.  WIth the example of subscriptions, the resulting .to_element Element contains no reference back to the Subscription Plan that the user has subscribed to:

```
In [10]: e = sub.to_element()

In [11]: list(e)
Out[11]: 
[<Element 'uuid' at 0x102f48e90>,
 <Element 'state' at 0x102f48ed0>,
 <Element 'quantity' at 0x102f48f10>,
 <Element 'activated_at' at 0x102f48f50>,
 <Element 'canceled_at' at 0x102f485d0>,
 <Element 'expires_at' at 0x102f48650>,
 <Element 'current_period_started_at' at 0x102f48cd0>,
 <Element 'current_period_ends_at' at 0x102f48d90>,
 <Element 'trial_started_at' at 0x102f3abd0>,
 <Element 'trial_ends_at' at 0x102f3ab50>,
 <Element 'unit_amount_in_cents' at 0x102f3a610>,
 <Element 'total_billing_cycles' at 0x102f3aad0>,
 <Element 'currency' at 0x102f4a0d0>,
 <Element 'subscription_add_ons' at 0x102f4a150>,
 <Element 'account' at 0x102f4a1d0>]
```

items.title: Signature Signing Incorrect?
items.body:
I was testing my Java Port of the signature signing mechanism. I was using the Python version of the signature signing as a reference test. I could not get the Java Version of the signature to match the Python version. I also tried several online tools for signature signing and they would agree with the Java Version of my output and not the Python version. After a long head scratching, i think the bug is in Python version.

The python code in question in js.py

```
key = hashlib.sha1(PRIVATE_KEY).digest()
signer = hmac.new(key, message, hashlib.sha1)
```

shouldn't it be the following?

```
signer = hmac.new(PRIVATE_KEY, message, hashlib.sha1)
```

The test case i was using is:

```
PRIVATE_KEY = '0cc86846024a4c95a5dfd3111a532d13'
js.sign_billing_info_update("ABC", 1312701386)
```

the message it would produce is :

```
[1312701386,billinginfoupdate,[account_code:ABC]]
```

Output:
`'94c1af938a64b0d535dab615f7ba62cea9ffbc6f-1312701386'`

So the signature is
`'94c1af938a64b0d535dab615f7ba62cea9ffbc6f'`

And when using online tool or my Java Program is the following:
`'6afcdb714a0eae4d68048649f25677c3fa780257'`

Online Tool Used: 
http://hash.online-convert.com/sha1-generator

BTW, i was trying to replicate the signature generation example on the recurly site using the test key and test timestamp.
http://docs.recurly.com/recurlyjs/signatures/spec

-Talib
